issues.description: The template provides an addGuestStudents method with the signature addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) while the problem statement (UML and task description) and the solution expect addGuestStudents(int) (a single int parameter). This parameter mismatch is structural: students are instructed to implement addGuestStudents(int) but the template already contains a stub with a different signature, which is likely to confuse them and lead to incorrect implementations or wasted effort.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem statement and solution by changing the template method signature to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (remove the boolean validateInput parameter). If validation behavior is desired, implement it inside that single-parameter method or add a clearly-documented private helper; otherwise, update the problem statement/UML to explicitly include the boolean parameter if that was the intended design.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a method addGuestStudents(int) (single int parameter). The solution implements public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (single parameter). However, the template declares public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) — an extra boolean parameter. This mismatch in the method signature (extra parameter name validateInput) creates a mapping confusion: students reading the task expect a one-parameter method and tests will target addGuestStudents(int), but the template presents a different signature. This forces students to reconcile differing method signatures (possibly leading to implementing an overloaded method or modifying the template) rather than focusing on the intended learning goal.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template method signature with the problem statement and solution by changing the template declaration to public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (remove the boolean validateInput parameter). If validation behavior is desired, implement it internally inside the single-parameter method or provide an overloaded helper method but keep the student-facing API identical to addGuestStudents(int) as described in the exercise.
